Name: Unknown
Description: The construction class is not known.

Name: Wood, Wood frame
Description: Wood frame (modern) structures tend to be mostly low rise (one to three stories, occasionally four). Stud walls are typically constructed of 2x4 or 2x6 inch wood members vertically set 16 or 24 inches apart. These walls are braced by plywood or by diagonals made of wood or steel. Many detached single and low-rise multiple family residences in the United States are of stud wall wood frame construction.

Name: Wood, Light wood frame
Description: Light wood frame structures are typically not built in the United States but would be found in other countries, such as Japan. In Hawaii, this classification would include single wall (studless) construction framed with light timber trusses.

Name: Wood, Masonry veneer
Description: A wood-framed structure faced with a single width of non-load-bearing concrete, stone, or clay brick attached to the stud wall.

Name: Wood, Heavy timber
Description: Heavy Timber structures typically have masonry walls with heavy wood column supports, and floor and roof decks are 2-3 inch tongue-and-groove planks.

Name: Wood, Lightweight Cladding
Description: Non-structural cladding and linings (e.g., fiber cement, plywood) used in lightweight construction that uses timber or light gauge steel framing as the structural support system.

Name: Wood, Hawaii indigenous material
Description: Indigenous Hawaiian construction.

Name: Masonry, Masonry
Description: Use this option when the exterior walls are constructed of masonry materials, but detailed construction information is unavailable or unknown.

Name: Masonry, Adobe
Description: Adobe construction uses adobe (clay) blocks with cement or cement-clay mixture as mortar. The roof consists of a timber frame with clay tiles or, in some cases, metal roofing.

Name: Masonry, Rubble stone masonry
Description: Rubble stone masonry consists of low-rise perimeter load bearing walls composed of irregular stones laid as coursed or uncoursed rubble in a cement mortar bed, with floor and roof joists constructed with wood framing.

Name: Masonry, Unreinforced masonry bearing wall
Description: Unreinforced masonry buildings consist of structures in which there is no steel reinforcing within a load bearing masonry wall. Floors, roofs, and internal partitions in these bearing wall buildings are usually of wood.

Name: Masonry, Unreinforced masonry bearing frame
Description: Unreinforced masonry is used for infill walls of buildings with a bearing frame. In this structure type, the masonry is intended to be used not to support gravity loads, but to assist with lateral loads.

Name: Masonry, Reinforced masonry
Description: Reinforced masonry construction consists of load bearing walls of reinforced brick or concrete-block masonry. Floor and roof joists constructed with wood framing are common.

Name: Masonry, Reinforced masonry shear wall with mrf
Description: Reinforced masonry construction consists of load bearing walls of reinforced brick or concrete-block masonry. Reinforced masonry buildings with "Moment Resisting Frames" carry lateral loads by bending. "Shear Walls" are continuous reinforced brick or reinforced hollow concrete block walls extending from the foundation to the roof and can be exterior walls or interior walls.

Name: Masonry, Reinforced masonry shear wall w/o mrf
Description: Reinforced masonry construction consists of load bearing walls of reinforced brick or concrete-block masonry. "Shear Walls" are continuous reinforced brick or reinforced hollow concrete block walls extending from the foundation to the roof and can be exterior walls or interior walls.

Name: Masonry, Joisted masonry
Description: Masonry exterior walls with roof of combustible materials on non-combustible supports.

Name: Masonry, Confined Masonry
Description: Confined masonry is a construction system in which plain masonry walls are confined on all four sides by reinforced concrete or reinforced masonry members. The walls themselves, however, carry all of the gravity and lateral loads.

Name: Masonry, Cavity Double Brick
Description: An unreinforced masonry construction type composed of two layers of bricks, common in many cities in Australia.

Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete
Description: Reinforced concrete buildings consist of reinforced concrete columns and beams. Use this if the other technical characteristics of the building are unknown.

Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete shear wall w/ mrf
Description: Building constructed with reinforced concrete columns and beams, as well as reinforced concrete floor and roof. "Moment Resisting Frames" carry lateral loads by bending. "Shear Walls" are continuous reinforced concrete extending from the foundation to the roof and can be exterior walls or interior walls.

Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete shear wall w/o mrf
Description: Building constructed with reinforced concrete columns and beams, as well as reinforced concrete floor and roof. Reinforced concrete Shear Walls are continuous reinforced concrete, extending from the foundation to the roof and can be exterior walls or interior walls. This category typically consists of buildings with a concrete box structural system with shear walls. The entire structure, along with the usual concrete diaphragm, is typically cast in place.

Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete mrf ductile
Description: Buildings constructed with reinforced concrete columns, beams, and slabs. Moment Resisting Frames carry lateral loads due to earthquakes by bending. This kind of structural system can sustain large deformations and absorb energy without brittle failure.

Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete mrf non-ductile
Description: Buildings constructed with reinforced concrete columns, beams, and slabs. Moment Resisting Frames carry lateral loads due to earthquakes by bending. These structures have insufficient reinforcing steel embedded in the concrete and thus display low ductility.

Name: Concrete, Tilt-up
Description: Tilt-up buildings are constructed with reinforced concrete wall panels that are cast on the ground and then tilted upward into their final positions. These wall units are then anchored to the foundation and attached to each other. The roof and floor decks are typically wood. More recently, the wall panels are fabricated off-site and trucked in. These buildings tend to be one or two stories in height.

Name: Concrete, Pre-cast concrete
Description: The pre-cast frame is essentially a post and beam system in concrete in which columns, beams, and slabs are prefabricated and assembled on site.

Name: Concrete, Pre-cast concrete w/ shear wall
Description: The pre-cast frame is essentially a post and beam system in concrete in which columns, beams, and slabs are prefabricated and assembled on site. Lateral loads due to earthquakes are carried by cast-in-place concrete "shear" walls.

Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete mrf
Description: A building constructed with reinforced concrete columns, beams, and slabs. "Moment-resisting frames" carry lateral loads due to earthquakes by bending. Information on the reinforcing steels is not sufficient to determine the building level of ductility.

Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete mrf with URM
Description: Reinforced concrete columns and beams form "moment-resisting frames" to carry lateral loads due to earthquakes. Unreinforced masonry walls are used as infills between the columns to add lateral load resistance, but are not intended to serve as gravity load-bearing elements.

Name: Steel, Steel
Description: Steel frame buildings consist of steel columns and beams. Use this if the other technical characteristics of the building are unknown.

Name: Steel, Light metal
Description: Light metal buildings are made of light gauge steel frame and are usually clad with lightweight metal or asbestos siding and roof, often corrugated. They typically are low-rise structures.

Name: Steel, Braced steel frame
Description: Buildings constructed with steel columns and beams that are braced with diagonal steel members to resist lateral forces.

Name: Steel, Steel mrf perimeter
Description: Buildings constructed with steel columns and beams that are braced with diagonal steel members to resist lateral forces.

Name: Steel, Steel mrf distributed
Description: Buildings constructed with steel columns and beams to carry lateral loads distributed throughout the building. The diaphragms are usually concrete, sometimes over steel decking. This structural type is seldom used for low-rise buildings.

Name: Steel, Steel mrf
Description: Steel MRF buildings consist of structural steel columns and beams. Lateral loads due to earthquakes are carried by the "moment-resisting frames," but the locations of the moment-resisting frames in the building are unknown.

Name: Steel, Steel frame w/ URM
Description: Structural steel columns and beams form "moment-resisting frames" to carry lateral loads due to earthquakes. Unreinforced masonry walls are used as infills between the columns to add lateral load resistance, but are not intended to serve as vertical load-bearing elements. Sometimes the steel frames are completely hidden in the masonry walls.

Name: Steel, Steel frame w/ concrete shear wall
Description: Structural steel columns and beams form exterior frames, but the joints are not designed for moment resistance. Lateral loads due to earthquakes are carried by reinforced concrete "shear" walls. The concrete walls are continuous from the foundation to the roof.

Name: Steel, Steel reinforced concrete
Description: Structural steel sections (beams and columns) are encased in reinforced concrete. The encased structural steel columns are sometimes discontinued in the upper portions of the buildings, making the columns in the upper floor regular reinforced concrete columns.

Name: Steel, Steel long span
Description: Steel long-span buildings create unobstructed, column-free spaces greater than 100 feet for a variety of activities or functions. These include activities where visibility is important for large audiences (e.g., auditoriums and covered stadiums), where flexibility is important (e.g., exhibition halls and certain types of manufacturing facilities), and where large movable objects are housed. Two-hinge (made of a single member hinged at each end) and three-hinge (made of two members hinged at each end and at the meeting point at the crown) trussed arches are widely used.

Name: Composite, FM – Fire res RC Apt. Masonry dwellings
Description: New residential fire code; concrete, concrete block, masonry, stone, fire-resistant dwellings.

Name: Composite, FT – Fire res non-apt dwl RC mas/stl
Description: New residential fire code; steel, semi-fire-resistant.

Name: Composite, FH – Dwellings other than FM, FT
Description: New residential fire code; other dwellings.

Name: Composite, F1 – Fire res RC and masonry bldg
Description: New commercial fire code; concrete, concrete block, masonry, stone, fire-resistant dwellings.

Name: Composite, F2 – Semi-fire res and steel bldg
Description: New commercial fire code; steel, semi-fire-resistant.

Name: Composite, F3 – Buildings other than F1,F2
Description: New commercial fire code; other dwellings.

Name: Composite, A: Fire-resistive dwellings
Description: Main structure (column, beam, and floor) is constructed of concrete or steel covered with noncombustible material. Roof and external walls are built using nonflammable material.

Name: Composite, B: Semi-fire-resistive dwellings
Description: (1) External walls consist of any one of the following: concrete, concrete material, brick or stone masonry. (2) Steel structure with external walls of nonflammable material or covered with noncombustible material.

Name: Composite, C: Slow-burning dwellings
Description: (1) Wood frame with external walls of any of the following: cement or mortar plating, stone pitching or tile hinging. (2) Steel structure that does not come under Class B. Excluding building with external walls of boarding and/or synthetic resin hanging and/or cloth hanging.

Name: Composite, D: Dwelling other than A, B or C
Description: Building other than Class A, B, and C.

Name: Composite, Sp: Fire-resistive concrete buildings
Description: Main structure (column, beam, and floor) is constructed of concrete and all external walls are of any one of the following: concrete, concrete material, brick, or stone masonry.

Name: Composite, 1: Fire-resistive buildings other
Description: (1) Main structure (column, beam, and floor) is constructed of concrete or steel covered with noncombustible material. Roof and external walls are built using nonflammable material. (2) Main structure (column, beam, and floor) is constructed of wood and/or steel covered with noncombustible material. Roof and external walls are built of or covered by nonflammable and/or semi-nonflammable material. Column, beam, floor, and external walls are to be resistant against the heat under normal fire conditions for at least 1 hour.

Name: Composite, 2: Semi-fire-resistive buildings
Description: (1) External walls consist of any one of the following: concrete / concrete block / brick / stone masonry. (2) Steel structure with external walls of nonflammable and/or semi-nonflammable material or covered with noncombustible material. (3) Main structure (column, beam, and floor) is constructed of wood and/or steel covered with noncombustible material. Roof and external walls consist of or are covered by nonflammable and/or semi-nonflammable materials. Column, beam, floor, and external walls to be resistant against the heat under normal fire conditions for at least 45 minutes.

Name: Composite, 3: Slow-burning buildings
Description: (1) Wood frame (and not applicable to Class 1 or 2) with external walls of nonflammable and/or semi-nonflammable material or covered with noncombustible material. (2) Steel structure that does not come under Class 1 or 2. Excluding building with external walls of boarding and/or synthetic resin hanging and/or cloth hanging.

Name: Composite, 4: Other than Sp, 1, 2, or 3
Description: Buildings other than Class SP, 1, 2, and 3.

Name: Special, Long-span
Description: Building constructed with steel frame and metal siding and roof of wood or other combustible material. Typically gymnasiums or auditoriums.

Name: Special, Semi-wind resistive
Description: A building for which a licensed engineer does not design the structure, but an attempt is made to build in accordance with an accepted wind building code; code compliance is not assured. Some engineering input may have occurred. Most of the details in a wind resistive structure are found in a semi-wind resistive structure, but not all components are wind resistive.

Name: Special, Wind resistive
Description: A structure that was designed by a licensed engineer to comply with the wind code. Characterized by the presence of properly sized wind-resistant connectors, adequate bracing, and a continuous load path from the roof to the foundation (i.e., the roof is tied to the walls, the floors are attached to each other, and the walls are tied to the foundation).

Name: Special, Unknown glass
Description: Code for the U.S. Hurricane Plate Glass Module when the type of glass is unknown

Name: Special, Safety glass
Description: Safety glass includes fully tempered and laminated glass. Fully tempered glass is created by heating common annealed glass uniformly to make a high-strengthened glass. Laminated glass is made by sandwiching a plastic sheet between two glass panels, which prevents shattering and helps maintains the integrity of the building envelop even after its breakage.

Name: Special, Impact resistance glass
Description: Impact-resistant glass similar to laminated glass (as described above), which has been tested to resist breakage from flying debris during hurricanes. Impact-resistant glass is typically thicker than safety glass and is packaged as a unit that includes a special frame.

Name: Special, Basement Flood Loss - High Value
Description: Buildings with high-value equipment stored in the basement such as subways and other buildings with generators located in the basement etc. which are very sensitive to flood.

Name: Special, Flood Resistance General
Description: Buildings in general, designed and built with good flooding resistances, excluding bridges, dams and water tower having minimal flood damage

Name: Mobile Homes, Mobile Homes
Description: Represents a weighted average of tie-down types, including no tie-downs. Use this code for a mobile home (manufactured home) when the tie-down information is unknown.

Name: Mobile Homes, Mobile homes no tie down
Description: Use this code for a mobile home (manufactured home) with no anchoring systems present.

Name: Mobile Homes, Mobile homes part tie down
Description: Use this code for a mobile home (manufactured home) when the tie-downs are either over-the-top ties or frame ties, but not both, or with fewer ties than recommended by the manufacturer.

Name: Mobile Homes, Mobile homes full tie down
Description: Use this code for a mobile home (manufactured home) when the anchoring system uses both over-the-top ties and frame ties. Typically, ten frame ties and seven over-the-top ties are required for full tie-down in single-wide mobile homes.

Name: Mobile Homes, Double Wide
Description: Same as Mobile homes tied down but having double width living unit and in general more wind resistive

Name: Bridges, Unknown Bridge
Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges with individual span length less than 500 feet with unknown material of construction, unknown number of spans, and unknown support conditions, or other unknown bridges that cannot be mapped to any of the other bridge construction class codes.

Name: Bridges, Conventional multiple span bridges
Description: Bridges having multiple simple spans with each span being less than 500 feet. These bridges may be constructed of concrete, steel, or timber.

Name: Bridges, Conventional continuous bridges
Description: Bridges having continuous spans of less than 500 feet. These bridges may be constructed of concrete, steel, or timber.

Name: Bridges, Major bridges
Description: Bridges having individual spans of 500 feet or more. These bridges may be constructed of concrete or steel.

Name: Bridges, Multispan simply supported CONCRETE
Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of concrete and consisting of multiple simply supported spans, with individual span length less than 500 feet, spanning between consecutive piers and between abutments and piers.

Name: Bridges, Multispan simply supported STEEL
Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of steel and consisting of multiple simply supported spans, with individual span length less than 500 feet, spanning between consecutive piers and between abutments and piers.

Name: Bridges, Single Span Bridge
Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of steel or concrete and with a single span less than 500 feet spanning between abutments without intermediate piers. For single span bridges, the construction material does not matter.

Name: Bridges, General Concrete
Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of concrete with individual span length less than 500 feet, unknown number of spans, and unknown support conditions.

Name: Bridges, General Steel
Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of steel with individual span length less than 500 feet, unknown number of spans, and unknown support conditions.

Name: Bridges, Multispan continuous CONCRETE
Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of concrete and consisting of multiple continuously supported spans, with individual span length less than 500 feet, spanning between consecutive piers and between abutments and piers.

Name: Bridges, Multispan continuous STEEL
Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of steel and consisting of multiple continuously supported spans, with individual span length less than 500 feet, spanning between consecutive piers and between abutments and piers.

Name: Railways, General
Description: General railways or railroads of unknown rail typology

Name: Highways, General
Description: General highways or pavements constructed of either concrete, asphalt, or gravel

Name: Pavements, Runways
Description: Concrete or asphalt airport runways.

Name: Highways, Motorways
Description: Motorway: restricted access major divided highway (i.e. freeway), normally with 2 or more running lanes plus emergency hard shoulder

Name: Highways, Trunk road
Description: Trunk: the most important roads in a country's system that aren't motorways (not necessarily be a divided highway)

Name: Highways, Primary roads
Description: Primary: the next most important roads in a country's system (often link larger towns)

Name: Highways, Seconday roads
Description: Secondary: the next most important roads in a country's system (often link towns)

Name: Highways, Tertiary roads
Description: Tertiary: the next most important roads in a country's system (often link smaller towns and villages)

Name: Highways, Unclassified roads
Description: Unclassified: the least important through roads in a country's system (often link villages and hamlets)

Name: Highways, Residential roads
Description: Residential: roads which serve as an access to housing, without function of connecting settlements. Often lined with housing.

Name: Highways, Service road
Description: Service: access roads to, or within an industrial estate, camp site, business park, car park etc.

Name: Railways, light rail
Description: Light rail: a higher-standard tram system, normally in its own right-of-way. Often reaches a considerable length (tens of kilometer)

Name: Railways, Monorail
Description: Monorail: a single-rail railway

Name: Railways, Standard gauge
Description: Rail: full sized passenger or freight trains in the standard gauge for the country or state

Name: Railways, Subway
Description: Subway: a city passenger underground rail service running mostly grade separated

Name: Railways, Tram
Description: Tram: one or two carriage rail vehicles, usually sharing motor road.

Name: Dams, Concrete dams
Description: Poured in place reinforced concrete dams.

Name: Dams, Earthfill dams
Description: Dams constructed from earth.

Name: Dam, General
Description: Dams in general where material or type is unknown

Name: Tunnels, Unknown Tunnel
Description: Lined or unlined tunnels with unknown material and unknown method of construction, or other tunnels that cannot be mapped to any of the other tunnel construction class codes.

Name: Tunnels, Alluvium tunnels
Description: Tunnels that were drilled through unconsolidated sedimentary deposits and then typically lined with concrete.

Name: Tunnels, Rock tunnels
Description: Rock tunnels are lined or unlined tunnels that were drilled through rock.

Name: Tunnels, Cut and cover tunnels
Description: Tunnels that were constructed by cutting a trench, installing a liner, and then covering the liner with earth.

Name: Tunnels, Rock Cut and Cover Tunnels
Description: Lined or unlined rock tunnels constructed after excavating a trench and roofing over with an overhead support system.

Name: Tunnels, Alluvial Cut and Cover Tunnels
Description: Lined or unlined alluvium tunnels constructed after excavating a trench and roofing over with an overhead support system.

Name: Tunnels, Alluvial Bored Tunnels
Description: Lined or unlined tunnels constructed through alluvium soil using a boring machine.

Name: Tunnels, Rock Bored Tunnels
Description: Lined or unlined tunnels drilled through rock using a boring machine.

Name: Tanks, Unknown Tanks
Description: Storage tanks with an unknown material, unknown location, and unknown contents, or other unknowns that cannot be mapped to any of the other storage tank construction class codes.

Name: Tanks, Underground Liquid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks made of steel or concrete for holding liquids and located under the ground.

Name: Tanks, Underground Solid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks made of steel or concrete for holding solid material and located under the ground.

Name: Tanks, On Ground Liquid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks located on the ground surface for holding liquids with an unknown material of construction.

Name: Tanks, On Ground Steel liquid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks made of steel for holding liquids and located on the ground surface.

Name: Tanks, On Ground Concrete liquid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks made of concrete for holding liquids and located on the ground surface.

Name: Tanks, On Ground Solid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks located on the ground surface for holding solid material with an unknown material of construction.

Name: Tanks, On Ground Steel solid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks made of steel for holding solid material and located on the ground surface.

Name: Tanks, On Ground Concrete solid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks made of concrete for holding solid material and located on the ground surface.

Name: Tanks, Elevated Liquid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks located above the ground surface for holding liquids with an unknown material of construction.

Name: Tanks, Elevated Steel liquid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks made of steel for holding liquids and located above the ground surface.

Name: Tanks, Elevated Concrete liquid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks made of concrete for holding liquids and located above the ground surface.

Name: Tanks, Elevated Solid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks located above the ground surface for holding solid material with an unknown material of construction.

Name: Tanks, Elevated Steel solid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks made of steel for holding solid material and located above the ground surface.

Name: Tanks, Elevated Concrete solid Tanks
Description: Storage tanks made of concrete for holding solid material and located above the ground surface.

Name: Pipelines, Unknown Pipeline
Description: Pipelines with an unknown location and material, or other unknown pipelines that cannot be mapped to any of the other pipeline construction class codes.

Name: Pipelines, General Underground Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground with an unknown material of construction.

Name: Pipelines, Underground Cast Iron Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground and made of cast iron material.

Name: Pipelines, Underground Asbestos Cement Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground and made of asbestos-cement material.

Name: Pipelines, Underground Concrete Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground and made of concrete material.

Name: Pipelines, Underground PVC Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground and made of PVC material.

Name: Pipelines, Underground Ductile Iron Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground and made of ductile iron material.

Name: Pipelines, General At Grade Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground with an unknown material of construction.

Name: Pipelines, At Grade Cast Iron Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground and made of cast iron material.

Name: Pipelines, At Grade Asbestos Cement Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground and made of asbestos-cement material.

Name: Pipelines, At Grade Concrete Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground and made of concrete material.

Name: Pipelines, At Grade PVC Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground and made of PVC material.

Name: Pipelines, At Grade Ductile Iron Pipelines
Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground and made of ductile iron material.

Name: Chimneys, Masonry chimneys
Description: Masonry chimneys over 30 feet high.

Name: Chimneys, Concrete chimneys
Description: Reinforced concrete chimneys over 30 feet high.

Name: Chimneys, Steel chimneys
Description: Steel chimneys over 30 feet high.

Name: Towers, Electrical transmission conventional
Description: Steel towers under 100 feet high designed to hold up electrical transmission lines.

Name: Towers, Electrical transmission major
Description: Steel towers over 100 feet high designed to hold up electrical transmission lines.

Name: Towers, Broadcast towers
Description: Steel towers designed to carry radio, TV, or cell phone transmission equipment.

Name: Towers, Observation towers
Description: Elevated towers designed for people to look out of, such as airport control or fire observation towers.

Name: Towers, Offshore towers
Description: Offshore towers are towers with a platform that are anchored to the ground under the ocean.

Name: Distribution Circuits
Description: Distribution circuits designed to carry radio, TV, or cell phone transmission equipment.

Name: Equipment, Residential equipment
Description: Residential furnishings including furniture and appliances.

Name: Equipment, Office equipment
Description: Office furniture, file cabinets, PCs, etc.

Name: Equipment, Electrical equipment
Description: Non-high tech electrical equipment other than electrical equipment included as part of the function of the building.

Name: Equipment, Mechanical equipment
Description: All equipment not otherwise classified in a building.

Name: Equipment, High-technology equipment
Description: Sensitive equipment easily damaged by shaking.

Name: Equipment, Trains, trucks, airplanes etc.
Description: Any type of train, truck, or airplane.

Name: Equipment, Thermal Power Plant
Description: Thermal power plants are energy centers that convert heat energy into electrical energy. In Japan, heat is usually generated by fuel, coal, or nuclear. Plants typically include components, such as boilers (or reactors), gas turbines, pumps, generators, cooling towers, power transmission lines, substations, transformers, bushings, circuit breakers/switches, waste management facilities, and building structures supporting operation of the plant or for administrative purposes.

Name: Automobiles, Unknown HAZUS
Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation. Use this code for unknown automobiles in general or for HAZUS unknown classification.

Name: Automobiles, Personal
Description: Typically a four-wheeled personal automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation.

Name: Automobiles, Dealers
Description: Typically a four-wheeled dealers (part of the fleet) automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation.

Name: Automobiles, 4 Wheeler
Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation.

Name: Automobiles, 2 Wheeler
Description: Typically a two-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation; may include a side car with a third wheel.

Name: Automobiles, G
Description: Off-road personal vehicle

Name: Motorcycles, Small
Description: A two-wheeled or three-wheeled vehicle with a maximum design speed of not more than 50 km/h

Name: Motorcycles, Large
Description: Mopeds, Motorcycles, Motor Tricycles and Quadricycles with a maximum design speed of more than 50 km/h

Name: Automobiles, M1
Description: Vehicles designed and constructed for the carriage of passengers and comprising no more than eight seats in addition to the driver’s seat, and having a maximum mass (“technically permissible maximum laden mass”) not exceeding 3.5 tons

Name: Buses, M2 + M3
Description: Vehicles designed and constructed for the carriage of passengers, comprising more than eight seats in addition to the driver’s seat

Name: Automobiles, M1 Low cost
Description: M1 type vehicle with value lower than average M1 car.

Name: Automobiles, M1 High cost
Description: M1 type vehicle with value higher than average M1 car.

Name: Automobiles, M1 Large fleet
Description: Typically a fleet from 51 up to 100 vehicles of M1 type.

Name: Automobiles, M1 Mid-size fleet
Description: Typically a fleet from 21 up to 50 vehicles of M1 type.

Name: Automobiles, M1 Small fleet
Description: Typically a fleet with up to 20 vehicles of M1 type.

Name: Cargo, N
Description: Power-driven vehicles having at least four wheels and used for the carriage of goods

Name: Trailers, O
Description: Trailers (including semi-trailers)

Name: Tractor trailers, OT
Description: Tractor trailers

Name: Mobile industrial machines, S
Description: Self-propelled industrial machines. Trailer industrial machines. Tractor trailer industrial machines.

Name: Tractors, T
Description: Agricultural and Forestry tractors

Name: Cars GEC, unknown GEC
Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation.

Name: Cars GEC, Compact
Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation with passenger and cargo volume between 100 cu. ft. (2830 l) and 109 cu. ft. (3110 l)

Name: Cars GEC, Large
Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation with passenger and cargo volume higher than 120 cu. ft. (3400 l)

Name: Cars GEC, Mid-Size
Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation with passenger and cargo volume between 110 cu. ft. (3110 l) and 119 cu. ft. (3395 l)

Name: Cars GEC, Pick-Up & Trucks and SUV
Description: Pick-Up & Trucks and SUV

Name: Cars GEC, Sub-Compact
Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation with passenger and cargo volume less than 99 cu. ft. (2830 l)

Name: Marine Craft, Pleasure Boats & Yachts
Description: Typically privately-owned boats that can be used for recreation, fishing, or cruising. This description is meant to exclude commercial vessels, such as cargo ships or tugboats. Use this construction code if the boat power/sail classification is unknown.

Name: Marine Craft, Pleasure Boats & Yachts - Power Boats
Description: A pleasure boat that is powered only by a motor (no sails).

Name: Marine Craft, Pleasure Boats & Yachts - Sail Boats
Description: A pleasure boat that is capable of being powered by wind through the use of sails. Boats that have both sails and a motor should be modeled under this code.

Name: Miscellaneous, Railway Property
Description: Railway properties are composed of major components of railway systems, which include railway stations, railway tunnels, railway bridges, railway tracks, and cables along the tracks but excluding trains.

Name: Miscellaneous, Pumping Station
Description: Pumping stations are structures with mechanical devices that are used typically when a fluid material must be raised from a low point to a point of higher elevation, or where the topography prevents downhill gravity flow.

Name: Miscellaneous, Compressor stations
Description: Compressor stations are structures with mechanical devices that are used for increasing the pressure of a gas by mechanically decreasing its volume.

Name: Miscellaneous, Cranes
Description: A machine for raising, shifting, and lowering heavy weights by means of a projecting swinging arm or with the hoisting apparatus supported on an overhead track.

Name: Miscellaneous, Conveyor systems
Description: Devices used for moving loose material (typically on a belt, on rollers, or in an auger).

Name: Miscellaneous, Canals
Description: An artificial waterway of any depth used for draining or irrigating land or for navigation.

Name: Miscellaneous, Earth retaining structures
Description: Earth retaining structures taller than 20 feet high.

Name: Miscellaneous, Waterfront structures
Description: Wharves or docks built next to the shore of navigable waters so that ships may receive and discharge cargo and passengers or walls of artificially enclosed basins into which vessels are brought for inspection and repair.

Name: Miscellaneous, Transit Warehouse
Description: Transit warehouses often refer to distribution centers that temporarily store various commodities for further distribution, including wholesale stores. The commodities can be light (e.g., food, drug, light fabrication of clothing, high technology electricals) and heavy (e.g., heavy construction machineries). Warehouses are typically one story steel frame or SRC (steel reinforced concrete) construction with high ceilings. Most of the commodities are well packed and can be stacked during storage.

Name: Miscellaneous, Marine Hull
Description: Marine hull insurance covers the hull and machinery of a vessel. Specific ports or docks include loading or unloading (port risk), under construction (builders risk), and repair (repairing risk).

Name: Miscellaneous, Treatment plant
Description: Treatment plants are structures and sites for the treatment of potable water or wastewater

Name: Marine Cargo, Unknown / General
Description: General / unknown marine cargo code.

Name: Marine Cargo, Carpool
Description: Open areas close to harbors where thousands of cars are gridded before being shipped on Personal Car Carriers (PCCs).

Name: Marine Cargo, General and Containerized Cargo
Description: Cubicles 8 feet in width, 8.5 feet in height, and 20 or 40 feet in length in which commodities are packed. Cubicles are usually stacked on ships, trains, or airplanes for long-distance transportation.

Name: Marine Cargo, Heavy Cargo
Description: Heavy cargos are usually heavy machinery that cannot be fit into a standard container, such as jack-up and semi-submersible rigs, dredging equipment, luxury yachts, offshore production modules and sub-sea structures, construction machinery, container cranes and harbor equipment, and complete factories. Vessels used for this type of cargo are usually semi-submersible heavy lift ships, conventional heavy lift ships, tow barges and dockships. Heavy cargo is sometimes containerized.

Name: Marine Cargo, Refrigerated Cargo
Description: Refrigerated cargo is similar to general containerized cargo, but with additional cooling equipment to keep commodities fresh. Commodities are commonly fruits and frozen goods. This type of containerized cargo requires an external source of power to maintain a temperature-controlled environment.

Name: Marine Cargo, Dry Bulk Cargo
Description: Dry bulk cargo refers to bare solid materials, such as coal, metal ore, lumber, and grains.

Name: Marine Cargo, Liquid Bulk Cargo
Description: Liquid bulk cargo refers to bare liquid material, such as oil, liquefied natural gas, and liquid chemicals. Liquid bulk cargo is generally stored in tank farms on shore.

Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Unknown Cargo
Description: Unknown marine cargo, Combustible.

Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Carpool
Description: Open areas close to harbors where thousands of cars are gridded before being shipped on Personal Car Carriers (PCCs).

Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: General and Containerized
Description: Cubicles 8 feet in width, 8.5 feet in height, and 20 or 40 feet in length in which commodities are packed. Cubicles are usually stacked on ships, trains, or airplanes for long-distance transportation.

Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Heavy Cargo
Description: Heavy cargos are usually heavy machinery that cannot be fit into a standard container, such as jack-up and semi-submersible rigs, dredging equipment, luxury yachts, offshore production modules and sub-sea structures, construction machinery, container cranes and harbor equipment, and complete factories. Vessels used for this type of cargo are usually semi-submersible heavy lift ships, conventional heavy lift ships, tow barges, and dockships. Heavy cargo is sometimes containerized.

Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Refrigerated Cargo
Description: Refrigerated cargo is similar to general containerized cargo, but with additional cooling equipment to keep commodities fresh. Commodities are commonly fruits and frozen goods. This type of containerized cargo requires an external source of power to maintain a temperature-controlled environment.

Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Dry Bulk Cargo
Description: Dry bulk cargo refers to bare solid materials, such as coal, metal ore, lumber, and grains.

Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Liquid Bulk Cargo
Description: Liquid bulk cargo refers to bare liquid material, such as oil, liquefied natural gas, and liquid chemicals. Liquid bulk cargo is generally stored in tank farms on shore.

Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Unknown Cargo
Description: Unknown marine cargo, Non-Combustible.

Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Carpool
Description: Open areas close to harbors where thousands of cars are gridded before being shipped on Personal Car Carriers (PCCs).

Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: General and Container
Description: Cubicles 8 feet in width, 8.5 feet in height, and 20 or 40 feet in length in which commodities are packed. Cubicles are usually stacked on ships, trains, or airplanes for long-distance transportation.

Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Heavy Cargo
Description: Heavy cargos are usually heavy machinery that cannot be fit into a standard container, such as jack-up and semi-submersible rigs, dredging equipment, luxury yachts, offshore production modules and sub-sea structures, construction machinery, container cranes and harbor equipment, and complete factories. Vessels used for this type of cargo are usually semi-submersible heavy lift ships, conventional heavy lift ships, tow barges, and dockships. Heavy cargo is sometimes containerized.

Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Refrigerated Cargo
Description: Refrigerated cargo is similar to general containerized cargo, but with additional cooling equipment to keep commodities fresh. Commodities are commonly fruits and frozen goods. This type of containerized cargo requires an external source of power to maintain a temperature-controlled environment.

Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Dry Bulk Cargo
Description: Dry bulk cargo refers to bare solid materials, such as coal, metal ore, lumber, and grains.

Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Liquid Bulk Cargo
Description: Liquid bulk cargo refers to bare liquid material, such as oil, liquefied natural gas, and liquid chemicals. Liquid bulk cargo is generally stored in tank farms on shore.

Name: Marine Cargo, Automobiles
Description: Motor vehicles being transported. Automobile cargoes can be in different storage conditions.

Name: Marine Cargo, Break Bulk
Description: Loose, non-containerized cargo that is loaded directly on a ship in bags, boxes, crates, etc. Examples of break bulk are paper rolls, barrels, plywood, and pipes.

Name: Marine Cargo, Dry Bulk
Description: Bare solid materials, such as coal, metal ore, wood pulp, and grains.

Name: Marine Cargo, Liquid Bulk
Description: Bare liquid material, such as oil, liquefied natural gas, and liquid chemicals. Liquid bulk cargo is generally stored in tank farms on shore.

Name: Marine Cargo, Consumables
Description: Food and beverage cargo. Can be in different storage conditions.

Name: Marine Cargo, Temperature-controlled
Description: Cargo that needs to be transported under specific temperature conditions, often refrigerated.

Name: Marine Cargo, Electronics
Description: Cargo that includes electronic devices such as computers, TVs, cell phones, circuits, etc. Can be in different storage conditions.

Name: Marine Cargo, Chemical Products
Description: Cargo that includes products of basic chemical manufacturing such as acids, alkalis, salts, and organic chemicals, as well as chemical products that are to be used in further manufacturing, including synthetic fibers, plastic materials, dry colors, and pigments. Can be stored in special conditions.

Name: Marine Cargo, Explosives
Description: Cargo that includes explosive material such as chemicals, fireworks, arms, etc. Can be stored in special conditions.

Name: Marine Cargo, General Cargo
Description: Cargoes that are not categorized under any other specific type, for example, clothing, staples, sport goods, etc.

Name: Marine Cargo, Heavy Industry
Description: Heavy machinery that cannot fit into a standard container, such as jack-up and semi-submersible rigs, dredging equipment, luxury yachts, offshore production modules and sub-sea structures, construction machinery, container cranes and harbor equipment, etc.

Name: Marine Cargo, Light Industry
Description: Cargo that includes the product of light fabrication industry. This can include household and office manufactured products such as fabrics, carpets, rugs, furniture, etc.

Name: Marine Cargo, Petroleum Products
Description: Cargo that contains petrochemical products such as oil, gas, and LNG. Can be stored in special conditions.

Name: Marine Cargo, Pharmaceuticals
Description: Cargo that contains pharmaceutical products. Can be in different storage conditions.

Name: Marine Cargo, Project Cargo
Description: Heavy cargo that includes components of special projects such as turbines for wind farms, railway cars, etc.

Name: Marine Cargo, Livestock
Description: Livestock being shipped.

Name: Marine Cargo, General Specie
Description: Statuettes, ornamental articles, fibers, arts and crafts, etc. that can be stored in different places such as in museums, in a house, or in warehouses. In each storage condition they can be stored under various degrees of protection.

Name: Marine Cargo, Fine Art & Collectibles
Description: Fine arts in the form of paintings, frames, sculpture, etc. that can be stored in different places such as in museums, in a house, or in warehouses. In each storage condition they can be stored under various degrees of protection.

Name: Marine Cargo, Cash In Transit
Description: Cash being transferred in various storage conditions.

Name: Marine Cargo, Jewelers Blocks
Description: Jewels, engravings, and valuable metals and stones stored in various conditions.

Name: Offshore, Unknown
Description: A structure that is anchored to the ground under the ocean. Platform construction class is unknown.

Name: Offshore, Caisson
Description: Caisson platforms use large diameter caissons to support a single well completion with a minimal deck. The deck is capable of supporting limited production, control equipment, and navigational aids. Caisson platform completions are limited to water depths of 100 feet or less.

Name: Offshore, Compliant Tower
Description: Compliant Towers consist of narrow, flexible towers and piled foundations that can support a conventional deck for drilling and production operations. Unlike fixed platforms, Compliant Towers withstand large lateral forces by sustaining significant lateral deflections and are usually used in water depths between 1,000 and 2,000 feet.

Name: Offshore, Fixed Jacket Platform
Description: Fixed platforms consist of jackets (a tall vertical section made of tubular steel members supported by piles driven into the seabed) with a deck placed on top, providing space for crew quarters, a drilling rig, and production facilities. Fixed platforms are economically feasible for installation in water depths up to 1,500 feet.

Name: Offshore, Jack-up
Description: Jackups are platforms that can be jacked up above the sea using legs that can be lowered like jacks. These platforms, used in relatively low depths, are designed to move from place to place and then anchor themselves by deploying the jack-like legs.

Name: Offshore, Mini Tension Leg Platform
Description: Mini Tension Leg Platforms (MTLP) are floating platforms of relatively low cost developed for production of smaller deepwater reserves that would be uneconomic to produce using more conventional deepwater production systems. They can also be used as a utility, satellite, or early production platform for larger deepwater discoveries.

Name: Offshore, Drill Rig
Description: Drill rig.

Name: Offshore, Semi Submersible Floating Production
Description: Semi-submersible floating production platforms have legs of sufficient buoyancy to cause the structure to float, but weight sufficient to keep the structure upright. These rigs can be moved from place to place and ballasted up or down by altering the amount of flooding in buoyancy tanks. They are generally anchored by cable anchors during drilling operations, though they can also be kept in place by the use of dynamic positioning. Semi-submersibles can be used in depths from 200 to 6,000 feet.

Name: Offshore, Drill Ship
Description: Drill ships are maritime vessels that have been fitted with drilling apparatuses. They are most often used for exploratory drilling of new oil or gas wells in deep water, but can also be used for scientific drilling. They are often built on modified tanker hulls and outfitted with dynamic positioning systems to maintain their position over a well. Drill ships are able to drill in water depths of over 6,500 feet.

Name: Offshore, SPAR Floating Production System
Description: SPARs consist of a large diameter single vertical cylinder supporting a deck. They have typical fixed platform topsides (surface decks with drilling and production equipment), three types of risers (production, drilling, and export), and hulls moored with taut caternary systems of six to 20 lines anchored into the seafloor. SPARs are generally used in water depths up to 3,000 feet.

Name: Offshore, Submersible Production System
Description: Floating vessels, usually used as mobile offshore drilling units (MODUs), that are supported primarily on large pontoon-like structures submerged below the sea surface. The operating decks are elevated 100 or more feet above the pontoons on large steel columns. Once on the desired location, this type of structure is slowly flooded until it rests on the sea floor. After the well is completed, the water is pumped out of the buoyancy tanks, and the vessel is refloated and towed to the next location. Submersibles operate in relatively shallow water, since they must rest on the seafloor.

Name: Offshore, Underwater Production Units, Completion
Description: Subsea Systems range from single subsea wells producing to a nearby platform, FPS, or TLP to multiple wells producing through a manifold and pipeline system to a distant production facility. These systems are presently used in water depths greater than 5,000 feet.

Name: Offshore, Tension Leg Platform
Description: Tension Leg Platforms (TLPs) consist of a floating structure held in place by vertical, tensioned tendons connected to the sea floor by pile-secured templates. Tensioned tendons provide for the use of a TLP in a broad water depth range with limited vertical motion. Larger TLPs have been successfully deployed in water depths approaching 4,000 feet.

Name: Offshore, Well Protector
Description: Well head protection structures.

Name: Offshore Renewables - General
Description: Covers offshore wind, hydrgogen, ocean wave, tidal, thermal and salinity gradient technologies and floating solar PV. It is preferred to separate these items if possible.

Name: Offshore Wind - General
Description: Covers Turbines, cables and substations. It is preferred to separate these items if possible.

Name: Offshore Wind - Turbine
Description: Offshore wind turbine. Key Loc fields to define the turbine are: PowerCapacity and FoundationType.

Name: Offshore Wind - Cable - General
Description: Covers Infield, Export, Transmission, and Interconnector cables. It is preferred to separate these items if possible.

Name: Offshore Wind - Cable - Infield
Description: Array cables connect wind turbines to each other and to the offshore substation. Also called 'inter-aray cables'.

Name: Offshore Wind - Cable - Export
Description: Export cables transfer power from offshore wind farms to connect to an onshore grid network typically via intermediate AC substations or DC converters. In some instances export cables can connect to an offshore grid system, as seen in Germany, or alternative end-use such as oil and gas platforms or industrial facility.

Name: Offshore Wind - Cable - Transmission
Description: Transmission cables connect an offshore shared platform to the onshore substation/converter.

Name: Offshore Wind - Cable - Interconnector
Description: Interconnectors are submarine cables that transfer electricity between two grids. They can be both domestic or international. 4C Offshore interconnectors database also contains ‘oil and gas electrification’ projects, which refer to subsea cables that powers oil and gas platform from shore.

Name: Offshore Wind - Onshore Substation
Description: Generally, the onshore substation will consist of switchgear, metering, transformers and associated plant. The onshore substation may also have reactive compensation equipment, depending on the network operator requirements and the design of the offshore network

Name: Offshore Wind - Offshore Substation
Description: Offshore substations are the systems that collect and export the power generated by turbines through specialized submarine cables. Can sometimes comprise HVDC conversion. Reactive (power) compensation platforms/stations can be included in this coding also.

Name: Onshore, Unknown
Description: A structure that is onshore. Construction class is unknown.

Name: Onshore Solar PV - General
Description: Covering all assets of a solar farm site and/or values that do not fit within any other PV construction site including supporting infastructure, roads, fencing, etc

Name: Onshore Solar PV - PV Module
Description: All information associated with the PV module includling racking/mouunting and panel values. Key Loc fields include tracking type, tilt angle, control type, module year, panel area, glass type and thickness.

Name: Onshore Solar PV - Inverter
Description: Central or string inverters from DC to AC including switchgear and protection systems.

Name: Onshore Solar PV - Transformer
Description: Covering inverter transformers, main step up transformers and their associated values.

Name: Onshore Solar PV - BESS
Description: Battery energy storage sytems, battery management, fire supression and cooling systems.

Name: Onshore Solar PV - Cabling / Combiner Boxes
Description: The electrical collection and transmission system, covering cabling, connectors, combiner boxes switches and surge protection devices.

Name: Onshore Solar PV - Monitoring and Control
Description: Covering SCADA, PPC, weather station, data acquisition and communication network assets.

Name: Onshore Wind Turbines
Description: Onshore wind turbines are installed individually, and in groups called "wind farms.". Wind turbine systems comprise a tower, hub and blades (the rotor), and nacelle (houses the generator). They are typically attached to a reinforced concrete foundation. Based on the wind characteristics of the site, these structures are generally designed to conform to the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) 61400-1 wind turbine design class.

Name: Forestry, Unknown
Description: Forestry, Unknown

Name: Forestry, Closed forest, Mainly evergreen forest
Description: Forestry, Closed forest, Mainly evergreen forest - the canopy is never without green foliage, but individual trees may shed their leaves (e.g. Sumatra, Atrato Valley (Colombia), Atlantic slopes of Costa Rica, Amazon Basin).

Name: Forestry, Closed forest, Mainly deciduous forest
Description: Forestry, Closed forest, Mainly deciduous forest - majority of trees shed their foliage simultaneously in connection to unfavourable season (e.g. North and South America, Southern slopes of the Himalayas and Europe)

Name: Forestry, Closed forest, Extremely xeromorphic forest
Description: Forestry, Closed forest, Extremely xeromorphic forest - dense stands of trees, composed by species such as bottle or tuft rees with succulent leaves (e.g. thorn forest in Southwestern North America and Southwestern Africa)

Name: Forestry, Woodland, Mainly evergreen woodland
Description: Forestry, Woodland, Mainly evergreen woodland - the canopy is never without green foliage, but individual trees may shed their leaves (e.g. Mediterranean Basin).

Name: Forestry, Woodland, Mainly deciduous woodland
Description: Forestry, Woodland, Mainly deciduous woodland - majority of trees shed their foliage simultaneously in connection to unfavourable season (e.g. Southern California and American Southeast, Mediterranean Basin)

Name: Forestry, Woodland, Extremely xeromorphic woodland
Description: Forestry, Woodland, Extremely xeromorphic woodland - dense stands of trees, composed by species such as bottle or tuft rees with succulent leaves (e.g. Southwestern North America and Southwestern Africa)

Name: Forestry, Scrub, Mainly evergreen scrub
Description: Forestry, Scrub, Mainly evergreen scrub - the canopy is never without green foliage, but individual species may shed their leaves (e.g. Mediterranean dwarf palm shrubland, Chaparral shrubland in California or Hawaiian tree fern thicket).

Name: Forestry, Scrub, Mainly deciduous scrub
Description: Forestry, Scrub, Mainly deciduous scrub - majority of scrub shed their foliage simultaneously in connection to unfavourable season (e.g. peat mosses in Scotland)

Name: Forestry, Scrub, Extremely xeromorphic (subdesert) shrubland
Description: Forestry, Scrub, Extremely xeromorphic (subdesert) shrubland - very open stands of shrubs, often composed by vegetation with green branches without leaves, some of them with thorns (e.g. mulga scrub in Australia).

Name: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mainly evergreen dwarf-scrub
Description: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mainly evergreen dwarf-scrub - mostly dense dwarf scrub evergreen dominating the landscape (e.g. East Mediterranean mountains).

Name: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mainly deciduous scrub
Description: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mainly deciduous scrub - majority of vegetation shed their foliage simultaneously in connection to unfavourable season (e.g. Sierra Nevada in California )

Name: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Extremely xeromorphic dwarf-shrubland
Description: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Extremely xeromorphic dwarf-shrubland - more or less open formations consisting of dwarf-shrubs or succulent species (e.g. Australia).

Name: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Tundra
Description: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Tundra - slowly growing, low formations, consisting mainly of dwarf-shrubs beyond the subpolar tree line (e.g. Alaska, Northern Canada, Greenland, Norway, Finland and Siberia).

Name: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mossy bog formations with dwarf-shrub
Description: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mossy bog formations with dwarf-shrub - peat accumulations formed mainly by mosses which generally cover the surface as well (e.g. Western Siberian Lowlands in Russia).

Name: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Tall graminoid vegetation
Description: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Tall graminoid vegetation - Mostly composed by tall grasslands with heights of over 2 m. Forbs can be presented but their coverage is less than 50% (e.g. Northeast Bolivia, African savannah and upper Nile Valley).

Name: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Medium tall grassland
Description: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Medium tall grassland - Mostly composed by grasslands with heights between 0.5 and 2 m. Forbs can be presented but their coverage is less than 50% (e.g. Sahel region in Africa, Eastern Kansas, glasslands in New Zealand)

Name: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Short grassland
Description: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Short grassland - Mostly composed by grasslands with heights below 0.5 m. Forbs can be presented but their coverage is less than 50% (e.g. alpine regions of Kenya, Colombia and Venezuela).

Name: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Forb vegetation
Description: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Forb vegetation - the plant community if mostly composed by forbs (more than 50%). (e.g. Sonoran Desert)

Name: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Hydromorphic fresh-water vegetation
Description: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Hydromorphic fresh-water vegetation - mostly composed by aquatic plants that are structurally supported by water, in wet or flooded regions most of the year (e.g. Amazon Basin)

Name: Forestry, Spruce
Description: Forestry, Spruce

Name: Forestry, Birch
Description: Forestry, Birch

Name: Forestry, Pine
Description: Forestry, Pine
